Award.AwardTitle: Planning Grant: I/UCRC in Sensory Sciences and Innovation
Award.AbstractNarration:
The research of the planned I/UCRC for Sensory Sciences and Innovation aims to support basic and applied research in several areas across the spectrum of chemosensory science, providing a focal point for industry-university collaboration. The planned center targets new understanding through multi-disciplinary, cross-cutting research of such topics as how flavors and fragrances influence memory, cognitive function and mood; the full range of benefits of flavors and fragrances in fighting infection (e.g., citral), supporting immune function and protecting food against spoilage (e.g. rosemary oil). The center vision seeks to transform the sensory sciences by integrating the discovery and characterization of taste and flavor molecules, with the study of their physiological and psychological mechanisms, to ultimately understand their effects on human behavior.

The flavor and fragrance industry represent a $ 23 B sector of the U.S. economy and is a critical driver of innovation across a broad range of consumer and industrial products from foods, beverages, and medicines, to personal care, home care and cosmetics. The planned I/UCRC?s holistic approach will likely lead to greater insights than the ?piecemeal? approach that is typically practiced in this field. Moreover, in cooperation with industry partners, the Center will establish a blueprint for training students and workers as multi-disciplinary sensory scientists. Partnering with industry will foster the rapid translation of this new knowledge into the next generation of innovative goods and services, resulting in broad societal impacts.

Background and Rationale:

The flavor and fragrance industry represent a $ 23 B sector of the U.S. economy and is a critical driver of innovation across a broad range of consumer and industrial products from foods, beverages, and medicines, to personal care, home care and cosmetics. Flavors and fragrances elicit complex chemosensory experiences that dramatically affect health, well-being and behavior, yet the nature of these experiences remains poorly understood. For example we do not understand how flavors and fragrances influence memory, cognitive function and mood. Nor do we understand the full range of benefits of flavors and fragrances in fighting infection, supporting immune function or protecting food against spoilage.

The proposed Industry/University Cooperative Research Center  (I/U CRC) in Sensory Sciences and Innovation is being formed to advance the sensory sciences through a better understanding of the effects of flavors and fragrances on human health, well-being and behavior. Since problems in the sensory sciences are highly multi-disciplinary, the solutions are likely to come from multi-disciplinary, cross-cutting strategies.   The Center will reside at Rutgers University in collaboration with our academic partners at the University of California at Riverside. Faculty who are involved in the Center come from a broad range of disciplines including chemistry, biochemistry, medicinal chemistry, chemical engineering, pharmaceutics, plant biology, food science, nutrition, computer science, psychology, neuroscience, economics, and marketing, and are national and international leaders in their respective fields. Collectively, SSI scientists have a long history of commitment to interdisciplinary research and are actively engaged in industry-sponsored fundamental and applied research.

Mission:

The Center’s mission is to (1) advance discovery and applications of flavors and aromas, (2) disseminate the scientific knowledge of flavors and aromas, and (3) educate new scientists who will contribute to these advances. The Center will support basic and applied research in several areas across the spectrum of chemosensory science, providing a focal point for industry-university collaboration.

Major Activities:

This planning grant supported a planning meeting for the exchange of ideas and perspectives among industry representatives and academic scientists with the goal of developing a research plan to best address the challenges and needs of the industry. These planning activities are intended to lead to the submission of a full proposal to establish an NSF-sponsored Industry/University Cooperative Research Center in Sensory Sciences & Innovation.

A 1-½ day planning meeting was hosted at Rutgers on November 6-7, 2014. The primary activities included: a presentation by the Center Director and Site Director on the vision, capabilities and value proposition of the Center; project proposal presentations by faculty followed by LIFE (Level of Interest and Feedback) Form execution; and review of LIFE forms and feedback on proposed projects. A technical poster session followed.

The primary objective of the Planning Meeting was to identify and vet a series of projects that would serve as the research agenda for the first year of operations of the proposed Center.  A second objective was to market the Center to potential industry sponsors to recruit new members.

Key Outcomes and Broader Impacts:

Representatives from 15 companies attended the planning meeting and participated in the LIFE Form evaluations. Industry representatives responded to 10 project presentations with their level of interest and feedback for improvement.  The projects were ranked resulting in a short-list of 6 projects that were prioritized for funding.
